DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China stated that sincerity is still key in the new round of China and US trade talks, according to Chinese press reports which noted that the two sides have shown sincerity in implementing the consensus reached by leaders of the two countries in Osaka and bringing the negotiations back on track. Furthermore, China reiterated it resumed the purchase of US farm produce and suggested that tariff escalations bring losses for both sides, while it also reiterated that both sides need to meet halfway and that getting a good restart won't be easy. (Xinhua)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson will not meet with any EU leaders until they agree to remove backstop, while an official spokesman said PM Johnson does want to meet EU leaders and negotiate, he will not want to "sit down and be told that the EU cannot possibly reopen the Withdrawal Agreement". (Telegraph)

UK PM Johnson said we need a new free trade deal with EU and that there is every chance the UK can get a deal, while he reiterated that we will come out with a deal or no deal on October 31st. (Newswires)

Scottish First Minister Sturgeon said she believes UK PM Johnson is looking for a no deal, regardless of what he says in public. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran Navy Commander Khanzadi said they will expand military ties with Russia and announced an agreement for joint naval exercise in the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, the Strait of Hormuz and the Persian Gulf. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump tweeted that the Fed “raised” way too early and way too much, while he added that their quantitative tightening was another big mistake. Furthermore, Trump also noted that EU and China will further lower interest rates and pump money into their systems, making it much easier for their manufacturers to sell product and that in the meantime, with very low inflation, the Fed does nothing and probably will do very little by comparison which he suggested was “too bad!". (Twitter)

Fed Candidate Shelton told Morning Money that she is not 'itching' to return to the gold standard and was wildly off the mark to suggest such a thing. (Morning Money)

 

MARKET RECAP

Equity indices were firmer in the European session before the SPX and Nasdaq-100 both sunk on the US equity open amid a lack of macro updates, but did pare back some of the losses throughout the session; however, the Dow Jones remained firmer thanks to some idiosyncratic tailwinds. Pfizer (PFE) closed lower after the co. posted mixed earnings and guided lower, as well as M&A talk with Mylan N.V. (MYL), who shot higher on the news that it would merge with Upjohn, Pfizer’s off-patent drug business. Anadarko Petroleum Corp (APC) fell after the co. posted earnings that beat on the top but missed on the bottom lines. Disney (DIS) was well supported as its live-action remake of The Lion King continued to break box office records. Boeing (BA) was under pressure following BBC reports that work on the 737 MAX production line was not sufficiently funded. Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) both moved lower, with the news that US President Trump wants to "scuttle" the USD 10bln Pentagon cloud contract that both tech co.’s are currently fighting for doing little to help. Apple (AAPL) advanced on positive news flow regarding the co.’s plans to use newly acquired Intel assets to produce its own modem before 2021 and on a price target raise at UBS. Lyft (LYFT) sunk on reports that COO McNiell, a former Tesla employee, is to leave the company. Grubhub (GRUB) closed higher after Just Eat (JE LN) agreed a GBP 9bln merger with Takeaway.com, lowering the overall number of market participants in the food delivery sector. Notable stocks moving higher after positive broker moves; Gilead Sciences (GILD) upgraded at RBC Capital, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) upgraded at Evercore ISI, AB InBev (BUD) upgraded at BAML, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) upgraded at Goldman Sachs. Notable stocks under pressure after negative broker moves; Starbucks (SBUX) downgraded at JP Morgan, Dish Networks (DISH), Dow Inc (DOW) downgraded at Citi and Susquehanna, PayPal (PYPL) downgraded at Guggenheim, American Airlines (AAL) downgraded at Macquarie, TripAdvisor (TRIP) downgraded at Vertical Group. S&P 500 -0.2% AT 3021, NASDAQ-100 -0.4% AT 7989, DJIA 0.1% AT 27221.

Treasuries moved higher to start the week, taking their cues from falling global yields and in anticipation of a Fed rate cut on Wednesday, in addition to the uncertainty from US-China trade talks in the next few days. No-deal Brexit fears surged as UK PM Johnson doubled down on the threat of a no-deal, just another global risk adding credence to central bank easing. US investors are also likely to be concerned by the evident slowdown in global manufacturing, which seeped into Friday’s US Q2 GDP data, despite the consumer segment remaining robust. At settlement the curve had flattened modestly (2s10s approximately 1bps narrower), with yields down between 1.5bps and 2.5bps. Elsewhere, US treasury said it borrowed (USD) 40bln in Q2 and that it expects to issue 433bln worth of debt in Q3 (higher than the prior 160bln estimate) and 381bln in Q4 of this year. US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks higher at 127-14+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 29th July 2019: Risk sentiment subdued ahead of key events
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude up
  • REAR VIEW: Sterling sinks on no deal fears; participants tentative as US-China trade talks commence
  • NEXT WEEK: Data: Japanese Unemployment & Industrial Output, Australian Building Approvals, German Gfk & CPI (Prelim), US PCE and Consumer Confidence, Events: BoJ Rate Decision, US & China Trade Negotiators meeting in China, Supply: Italy & Germany, Earnings: Apple, P&G, Mastercard, T-Mobile, Amgen, Eli Lilly, Altria, Orange, L’Oreal Bayer, BP.

* MARKET WRAP: Equity indices were firmer in the European session before the SPX and Nasdaq-100 both sunk on the US equity open amid a lack of macro updates, but did pare back some of the losses throughout the session; however, the Dow Jones remained firmer thanks to some idiosyncratic tailwinds. Treasuries and gold were bid ahead of risk events this week, such as the FOMC meeting on Wednesday and the initiation of US-China trade talks, where tentative participants were likely holding back from risk assets. The dollar was little changed on the day, with EurUsd trading tight, but Cable made fresh multi-year lows as UK PM Johnson wiped clean any doubts about his Brexit hard-line stance which had bolstered him to power.

* TRADE: Friday AMC US President Trump said he believes China will want to wait until the 2020 election to get a trade deal secured, therefore any updates from both sides regarding a time frame will be of note. Ahead of the US & China trade talks tomorrow, Xinhua reported China saying that “sincerity” is still key in the new round of talks, reiterating the need for both sides to meet halfway, and added that getting a good restart will not be easy. On the Japanese/South Korea front Sankei reported Japanese PM Abe is to forgo talks with his South Korean counterpart Moon at the UN in September. However, Yonhap reported that talks could come as soon as this week, according to sources.

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson will not meet with any EU leaders until they agree to remove backstop, the Telegraph reported. An Official Spokesman said while Mr Johnson does want to meet EU leaders and negotiate, he will not want to "sit down and be told that the EU cannot possibly reopen the Withdrawal Agreement". Earlier in the day, Johnson had called for a brand-new free trade deal with EU, saying that there is every chance the UK can get a deal. He then reiterated that "we will come out with a deal or no deal on October 31st". An upping of the stakes on Monday by Johnson followed news over the weekend, that he had set-up a ‘war cabinet’ of six Brexit supporting minsters, who are said to be working on leaving the EU on 31-Oct ‘by all means necessary’. RBC note that this is likely to rekindle the idea of preventing parliament from sitting. Also over the weekend; UK Chancellor Javid said that ‘all necessary funding will be made available’ to prepare for a no deal exit which is now, according to the man in charge of no deal preparations, Michael Gove, the base case scenario for the government. In terms of polling, the latest weekend polls show what the media is calling a ‘Boris bounce’: Conservative support has increased by 7 points to 30%, just ahead of Labour at 28%, with the poll suggesting that the Conservative gain came at the expense the Brexit party.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 7+ TICKS HIGHER AT 127-14+: Treasuries moved higher to start the week, taking their cues from falling global yields and in anticipation of a Fed rate cut on Wednesday, in addition to the uncertainty from US-China trade talks in the next few days. No-deal Brexit fears surged as UK PM Johnson doubled down on the threat of a no-deal, just another global risk adding credence to central bank easing. US investors are also likely to be concerned by the evident slowdown in global manufacturing, which seeped into Friday’s US Q2 GDP data, despite the consumer segment remaining robust. At settlement the curve had flattened modestly (2s10s approximately 1bps narrower), with yields down between 1.5bps and 2.5bps. Elsewhere, US treasury said it borrowed (USD) 40bln in Q2 and that it expects to issue 433bln worth of debt in Q3 (higher than the prior 160bln estimate) and 381bln in Q4 of this year. 

* WTI FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.67 HIGHER AT USD 56.87/BBL; BRENT (U9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.25 HIGHER AT USD 63.71/BBL: Prices ended firmer on Monday following some choppy trade in the earlier session. UK Foreign Minister Raab declaring that the UK would not consider a tanker swap with Iran, in addition to Iran restarting production at its Arak heavy-water reactor, both failed to provide support to the energy complex in the Asian/European session. However, prices rose gradually from the EU equity close through till US energy settlement, finding some support from rising equity indices and perhaps a reassessment of geopolitical risk, where US Secretary of State Pompeo expressed renewed concern about Iran’s nuclear pursuit and also comments from the Iranian VP urging China and other Iran-friendly nations to buy more of its crude. Elsewhere, oil demand remains an overhanging concern. US Q2 GDP data on Friday showed the first fall in business investment since 2015, echoing the global manufacturing slump. Additionally, participants will be paying close attention to the outcome of US-China trade talks in the coming days where a breakdown risks impeding Chinese oil demand (the world’s second largest oil consumer behind the US); UBS’ Daniel Ellis believes the outcome of the talks are crucial for the near-term outlook in crude.

* S&P 500 -0.2% AT 3021, NASDAQ-100 -0.4% AT 7989, DOW JONES 0.1% AT 27221, S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.6%, Consumer Staples 0.3%, Energy -0.3%, Financials -0.8%, Health Care 0.4%, Industrials -0.2%, Information Technology -0.1%, Materials -0.3%, Telecommunication Services -0.5%, Utilities 0.5%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Pfizer (PFE) closed lower after the co. posted mixed earnings and guided lower, as well as M&A talk with Mylan N.V. (MYL), who shot higher on the news that it would merge with Upjohn, Pfizer’s off-patent drug business. Anadarko Petroleum Corp (APC) fell after the co. posted earnings that beat on the top but missed on the bottom lines. Disney (DIS) was well supported as its live-action remake of The Lion King continued to break box office records. Boeing (BA) was under pressure following BBC reports that work on the 737 MAX production line was not sufficiently funded. Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) both moved lower, with the news that US President Trump wants to "scuttle" the USD 10bln Pentagon cloud contract that both tech co.’s are currently fighting for doing little to help. Apple (AAPL) advanced on positive news flow regarding the co.’s plans to use newly acquired Intel assets to produce its own modem before 2021 and on a price target raise at UBS. Lyft (LYFT) sunk on reports that COO McNiell, a former Tesla employee, is to leave the company. Grubhub (GRUB) closed higher after Just Eat (JE LN) agreed a GBP 9bln merger with Takeaway.com, lowering the overall number of market participants in the food delivery sector. Notable stocks moving higher after positive broker moves; Gilead Sciences (GILD) upgraded at RBC Capital, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) upgraded at Evercore ISI, AB InBev (BUD) upgraded at BAML, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) upgraded at Goldman Sachs. Notable stocks under pressure after negative broker moves; Starbucks (SBUX) downgraded at JP Morgan, Dish Networks (DISH), Dow Inc (DOW) downgraded at Citi and Susquehanna, PayPal (PYPL) downgraded at Guggenheim, American Airlines (AAL) downgraded at Macquarie, TripAdvisor (TRIP) downgraded at Vertical Group.

* FX WRAP:GBP was the standout underperformer; cable saw fresh 2-year lows as no deal Brexit fears intensified, with the downside likely compounded by a running of stops/technical selling. Cable now appears to have a clean run until support at 1.2160 (March 2017 low) and the key psychological 1.20 level (also the Jan 2017 low). The rest of G10 FX was comparatively benign; EUR firmer and USD flat, albeit trading within thin ranges ahead of key risk events later in the week; with EURUSD finding a floor just above last Friday’s 1.1112 low before consolidating around 1.1140. The antipodeans were equally subdued, if not a tad weaker on the firmer buck, whilst CAD took its cues from the crude complex. Safe havens were mixed; JPY was firm overnight (amid reports Japan’s GPIF began hedging overseas bond investments in a move which sources noted could spur other funds to follow suit) but pared gains to finish; USDJPY moving back above last Friday’s highs as the greenback strengthened. Conversely, CHF was a touch firmer. EMFX was a touch weaker as the dollar advanced, with the notable exceptions of TRY and ZAR; the former continuing to gain in wake of last week’s CBRT meeting (in which policy makers cut rates by a greater than expected 425bps, but indicated policy normalisation going forward) and the latter retracing some last week’s steep losses post Moody's 'credit negative' assessment of the Eskom bailout. BRL was uninspired, as participants eye Wednesday’s BCB meeting (25bps cut expected) and the pension reform process remains on ice due to parliamentary recess.

* GBP: Sterling sunk on Monday, as UK PM Johnson continued to strike a hard-line with the EU. Ahead of his election, some had perceived Johnson's comments to be pre-election bluster. However, since his appointment as PM, Johnson has remained defiant in his stance, which is also evident in the appointments he made to the Cabinet. If Johnson is serious about leaving with or without a deal on October 31st then markets will need to increasingly price out the possibility of an A50 extension and most likely an early snap general election. The issue in trying to get a deal other than the stalemate between the UK and EU is the Parliamentary arithmetic which remains a headache for the PM, particularly given opposition from within his own party who have raised the possibility of voting the government down in the event of a no deal Brexit. As such, a no deal outcome is becoming increasingly likely, with this perception boosted by recent UK press coverage which has centred around the ramp-up in no deal Brexit preparation by the UK government. However, adding to recent downside is the departure of the BoE (which is expected to stand pat on rates this Thursday) from a mildly hawkish to a neutral/dovish bias on interest rates, SocGen notes. “Though wage growth has accelerated nicely to 3.6%, one or more members could advocate lower rates to shadow US and ECB policy, and fears that the rhetoric of a no deal Brexit is sapping business confidence” the bank says. The danger for cable, SocGen concludes, remains to the downside and an acceleration towards 1.20.

Daily FX Wrap: Pound plummets as no-deal fears materialise
content:
GBP

The standout G10 underperformer as concerns over a disorderly Brexit snowballs, with weekend press noting that the UK government is intensifying funding for a no-deal Brexit, later followed by comments UK Foreign Secretary Raab and PM Johnson in which the former reaffirmed hard-lines in negotiations and the latter reiterated that the UK will come out of the EU on October 31st ,“deal or no deal”. Cable has retreated further from the 1.2350 mark and is poised to end the EU session sub-1.2300, having opened around 1.2375. For the technicians, not much to report on the support-front apart from the psychological round/half round numbers ahead of long-term supports at 1.2200 and then 1.2000.

DXY

The broad Dollar and Index continued to nudge higher, largely due to influence from the Brexit-battered Sterling mentioned above. DXY has extended gains above the 98.00 and surpassed last week’s highs (98.09) having traded in a 97.90-98.16 intraday range, with the next level to the upside at 98.37, the YTD high. However, further jawboning from US President Trump did prompt the DXY to come off highs as the US leader stated that “a small rate cut is not enough” ahead of the FOMC meeting on Wednesday. Looking ahead to tomorrow, US-China trade talks in Shanghai will draw the most attention, albeit expectations for a breakthrough has been played down by many US officials, instead markets will gauge the results of the talks by the timeframe between future meetings, if any.

EUR, AUD, NZD, JPY

All absorbing the impact of a firmer Dollar to an extent, but for different reasons. The single currency is cushioned via the EUR/GBP cross, which has extended gains above 0.9000 to a high of 0.9085 (vs. an open at 0.8990), thus EUR/USD is poised to end the European session little changed and in the middle of a 1.1113-40 parameter. Elsewhere, the antipodeans are eyeing the US-Sino discussions with AUD/USD hardly changed on the day and within a narrow 17 pip intraday range. Meanwhile, NZD/USD remains closer to the middle of a 0.6620-40 range having earlier tested its 50 DMA (0.6621) to the downside. Finally, an overall uneventful day for the JPY after initial overnight strength (amid reports Japan’s GPIF began hedging overseas bond investments in a move which sources noted could spur other funds to follow suit) waned shortly after with USD/JPY now back at pre-sources levels (having traded in a 108.42-70 intraday range) ahead of tonight’s BoJ’s monetary policy decision (full preview available in the Research Suite).

EM

The Turkish Lira has continued to strengthen in the aftermath of the CBRT’s deeper-than-forecast rate cut as the prospect of a normalising economy seemingly materialises. Analysts at SocGen also speculate that yield-seekers may be bypassing G10 currencies and instead chasing EM yields. USD/TRY is poised to end the session closer to the bottom of a 5.6050-6710 parameter

Upjohn will issue USD 12bln in debt where gross process will go to Pfizer, the new company will hold 24.5bln of total debt, Pfizer expects to generate 2020 revenue of roughly USD 40bln, expects to achieve income before tax in the mid-30 range with operating cash flow of USD 11-12bln. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has been initiated with a Buy at Goldman Sachs; analyst Katherine Fogertey noted that the co.’s sales are likely to continue to get a boost from low unemployment. Has an amazingly immersive, cinematic feel due to the comfy seats & surround sound audio… When full self-driving is approved by regulators, we will enable video while moving."

subject: UK PM Johnson says we need a new free trade deal with EU, there is every chance the UK can get a deal and that we will come out with a deal or no deal on October 31st
content: • We will do a grand new deal with EU based on a new free trade agreement
analysis_details: • GBP remains under pressure following these comments as Johnson continues to strike a hard-line with the EU. Ahead of his election, some had perceived Johnson's comments to be pre-election bluster. However, since his appointment as PM, Johnson has remain defiant in his stance and this can also be seen by the appointments he has made to his cabinet. If Johnson is serious about leaving with or without a deal on October 31st then markets will need to increasingly price out the possibility of an A50 extension and most likely an early snap general election. The issue in trying to get a deal other than the stalemate between the UK and EU is the Parliamentary arithmetic which remains a headache for the PM, particularly given opposition from within his own party who have raised the possibility of voting the government down in the event of a no deal Brexit. As such, a no deal outcome is becoming increasingly likely, with this perception also boosted by recent UK press coverage which has centered around the ramp-up in no deal Brexit preparation by the UK government.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] are little changed thus far, though the FTSE 100 (+1.1%) outperforms as sterling is subdued
  • Iranian Official said a meeting with parties relating the to 2015 nuclear deal was constructive, though unresolved issues remain
  • US & Japan are to have ministerial level talks in Washington on August 1st-2nd
  • Looking ahead, today’s calendar sees a lack of tier 1 highlights
  • Earnings: Simon Property Group, Baidu, Anadarko Petroleum

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week tentative as the upcoming slew of key risk events such as the resumption of US-China trade talks, heavy central bank activity including the FOMC and the latest US NFP jobs data, clouded over last Friday’s record highs on Wall St where tech earnings and better than expected US GDP underpinned stocks. As such, ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were mixed with tech and telecoms front-running the gains in Australia to push the benchmark index to record all-time high, while Tokyo sentiment was subdued by a firmer currency and with earnings in focus. Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) weakened amid modest expectations regarding the US-China trade talks in Shanghai this week and following a decline in Chinese Industrial Profits, with underperformance in Hong Kong after violent clashes over the weekend in protests that entered an 8th consecutive week. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded flat despite the weakness in Tokyo stocks, with demand for bonds subdued as participants were sidelined ahead of tomorrow’s BoJ policy announcement in which it is expected to maintain its policy settings of QQE with YCC control and NIRP at -0.10%.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8821 (Prev. 6.8796)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Jun) Y/Y -3.1% (Prev. 1.1%). (Newswires) Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Jun) Y/Y -2.4% (Prev. -2.3%).

As a reminder, US and China are to resume face-to-face trade talks in Shanghai this week, although reports noted expectations are modest and that no major breakthrough is anticipated. (Newswires/WSJ)

- China’s Foreign Minister hopes that the US will follow their commitment and create an enabling environment for upcoming discussions

Thousands of Hong Kong protesters clashed with police over the weekend in which dozens were arrested as protests regarding the extradition bill continued. (Newswires)

- China’s Hong Kong Affairs Office says no one should sit by and allow a few individuals to trample on the rule of law, and the central Government firmly support Chief Executive of Hong Kong Carrie Lam and the Hong Kong police. (Newswires)

US

US and Japan to have ministerial-level talks in Washington on August 1st-2nd, according to Japanese Economy Minister Motegi. (Newswires)

US Supreme Court ruled in favour of the Trump administration to permit it to shift military funds to use to construct the border wall. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Official Araqchi said emergency meeting with parties related to 2015 nuclear deal was constructive and unresolved issues remain, while he added Iran will continue to reduce its nuclear commitments if the EU cannot save the deal. (Newswires)

Iran Vice President says Iran's foreign policy is to protect multilateralism and confront US hegemony. (Newswires)

Chances are high that top diplomats from South Korea and Japan could have talks on the margins of a regional forum in Thailand this week., according to Yonhap citing sources. (Yonhap) 

UK/EU

UK Cabinet Minister Gove stated the government will make intensive efforts to get a better Brexit deal, but added we must operate on assumption we will not and that there will be a no-deal Brexit which we must be ready for. (Sunday Times) Further reports suggest that PM Johnson is to launch the largest advertising campaign since WW2 to get Britain ready for a no-deal Brexit, with an unprecedented marketing blitz on billboards, radio and television. (Telegraph) FT reports that UK chancellor of the exchequer, Sajid Javid, is preparing to announce more than GBP 1bln in increased funding for a no-deal Brexit, according to people familiar with the matter. (FT)

Institute for Government (IfG) has warned that there is no such thing as a managed no deal, and that predictions of a clean break from the EU made by hard Brexiteers will not occur. (Guardian)

UK Trade Minister Truss said the main priority is agreeing a FTA with the US and that she will be travelling to the US in the next few weeks for trade discussions, while there separate comments from US President Trump that they are already working on a US-UK free trade deal and that he will spend time with UK PM Johnson. (Newswires/Telegraph)

Confederation of British Industry report stated the EU have taken less action and are just as poorly prepared as the UK to cope with a no-deal Brexit, while it added the impact of crashing out will be felt for years. (FT)

ECB's Nowotny sees rates to be lower in the long-term than they have been historically and states that the ECB should strive for normalization. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Czech Republic at AA-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Finland at AA+; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European indices have largely started the week off mixed/flat [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C], though the FTSE 100 (+1.1%) is outperforming as sterling has continued to move lower throughout the session. Sectors are similarly mixed with some underperformance in the Auto sector, with auto names down in sympathy with Peugeot/PSA Group (-2.6%) afflicted by reports that the Co. are to move all production from their UK, Ellesmere Port to mainland Europe in the event that Brexit makes the plant unprofitable. Other notable movers include, Just Eat (+24.1%) and LSE (+14.9%) who are at the top of the Stoxx 600 and FTSE 100 after the confirmation of takeover discussions with Takeaway.com and sources indicating that the merger with Refinitiv is to be finalised within a week respectively. In contrast, at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 are Heineken (-5.3%) after the Co. reported operating profits of EUR 1.78bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.90bln for H1, though consolidated beer volume increased by 3.1% for the period. Finally, Novartis (-1.4%) are lower after the Co’s Paragon study just missed the statistical significance levels on its primary endpoints.

Pfizer (PFE) is expected to announce that they will combine their off-patent drug business with Mylan (MYL) resulting in a market value of around USD 9.5bln. (Newswires) For reference, Mylan are higher by around 25% in pre-market trade.

Ford (F) is to cut approximately 12k jobs in its European division by the end of 2020, with the Co. aiming for the majority of these to be through voluntary redundancy. (BBC)

A former engineer at Boeing (BA) has reportedly stated that work on the Co’s production line for the 737 Max was not sufficiently funded. (BBC)

FX

DXY - Another day of mild gains for the broad Dollar and index in a continuation from Friday’s GDP-induced momentum and ahead of an action packed week for the Buck, which will see the currency tackle US-China trade talks in Shanghai, the FOMC’s latest monetary policy decision, US ISM and jobs data. DXY gains more ground above 98.00 having eclipsed last week’s high (98.09) ahead of the YTD high at 98.37, meanwhile today’s docket sees a lack of Tier 1 data and no notable scheduled speakers (with the Fed on blackout until Wednesday evening)

GBP, EUR, JPY - The Pound has succumbed to further Brexit angst and has given up the psychological 1.2350 mark to the downside, with the move lower coinciding with usual punchy language from UK’s newly appointed Foreign Minister Raab, who reiterated hard lines on Brexit negotiations. As the prospect of a no-deal exit intensified, some desks are observing the declining GBP/USD 3-month risk reversals, which indicate that options skewing leans more towards Sterling weakness in the near-term. Cable has fallen to fresh 2yr lows and currently hovers just under 1.2325 with little by way of immediate tech levels to the downside. Elsewhere, the rising EUR/GBP cross has somewhat cushioned the single currency from Dollar headwinds, with EUR/GBP gaining further tractions above the 0.9000 level. Meanwhile, EUR/USD sees a cluster of options around 1.1100-10 (800mln) and 1.1135-50 (800mln) ahead of today’s NY cut. USD/JPY action is largely dictated by the Dollar ahead of this week’s key risk events and with the BoJ set to publish its latest monetary policy decision overnight. USD/JPY trades closer to the top of a 108.42-70 intraday range with 1bln in options expiring at strikes 108.95-109.05.

AUD, NZD - The antipodeans are somewhat resilient to an extent against the firmer Dollar and remain in tight intraday parameters following last week’s losses. Participants are keeping a close eye on US-Sino trade developments as delegates convene in Shanghai in an attempt to restart talks where it was left off, although officials from US have downplayed expectations of a breakthrough. AUD/USD currently trades a whisker away from 0.6900, with the next support level to the downside highlighted at 0.6890 ahead of the psychological 0.6850 while NZD/USD keeps its head above 0.6600.

TRY - Further gains for the Lira in the aftermath of the CBRT’s deeper-than-forecast rate cut as the prospect of a normalising economy seemingly materialises. Analysts at SocGen also speculate that yield-seekers may be bypassing G10 currencies and instead chasing EM yields. USD/TRY trades around 5.6370 and nearest to the bottom of a 5.6240-6710 parameter

South African President Ramaphosa must place strict limits on a plan to seize land without payment under policies to speed up transfers to the country’s black majority, a panel advising the South African president has said. (FT)

FX Expiries of Note:

- EUR/USD: 1.1100-10 (800M), 1.1135-50 (800M), 1.1200-15 (1BLN) 

- GBP/USD: 1.2400 (770M), 1.2535 (220M) 

- USD/JPY: 107.50 (1.8B), 108.0 (530M), 108.75-80 (460M), 108.95-109.05 (1B)

FIXED INCOME

A quiet start to the week for Bonds, as a lack of Tier 1 data points, central bank speakers or supply leaves a stimulus void ahead of a crucial week for central banks with both the Fed and BoE rate decisions occurring. Nonetheless, the Bund is firmer/flat this morning potentially deriving some respite from the quiet start after coming under pressure following Friday’s US GDP beat. Regarding the German 10-year, ING note that the short-term outlook is bullish with resistance levels ahead at 174.80; however, the bank adds that there is strong resistance between 175.20-30. Similarly, Gilts are firmer but generally little changed this morning just above 132.30 within a 15-tick range, amidst the lack of catalysts and ahead of Thursday’s BoE rate decision. Finally, and in-line with EU counterparts, USTs are experiencing a lacklustre start ahead of this week’s FOMC meeting, where expectations are in favour of a 25bps cut though focus will be on policy guidance; prior to Wednesday’s decision we have PCE and ADP data points while the US jobs release ends the week.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are also posting a relatively subdued start to the week, with prices little changed though they have regained the USD 56.00/bbl and USD 63.00/bbl levels to the upside respectively after a brief dip in the complex took them below these levels this morning. Some are attributing this dip to comments from Iran referring to emergency talks on a nuclear agreement as ‘constructive’ which may indicate a easing of tensions in the region which; though the dip was short-lived as there is no sign of respite for UK-Iranian tensions as a second UK warship arrives in the Gulf after Iran seized a UK tanker last week. On the complex, PVM notes that due to the lack of a convincing bullish move on Friday, WTI still has a viable objective to the downside as such a move below near-term support levels in todays session would be sufficient to move the complex lower. In terms of metals, Gold (U/C) is unchanged but towards the bottom of the days range on a lack of catalysts thus far ahead of this weeks aforementioned risk events, similarly copper prices are little changed on the lacklustre risk sentiment.

EQUITIES

European indices have largely started the week off mixed/flat [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%], though the FTSE 100 (+1.0%) is outperforming as sterling has continued to move lower throughout the session. Sectors are similarly mixed with some underperformance in the Auto sector, with auto names down in sympathy with Peugeot/PSA Group (-2.6%) afflicted by reports that the Co. are to move all production from their UK, Ellesmere Port to mainland Europe in the event that Brexit makes the plant unprofitable. Other notable movers include, Just Eat (+24.1%) and LSE (+14.9%) who are at the top of the Stoxx 600 and FTSE 100 after the confirmation of takeover discussions with Takeaway.com and sources indicating that the merger with Refinitiv is to be finalised within a week respectively. In contrast, at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 are Heineken (-5.3%) after the Co. reported operating profits of EUR 1.78bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.90bln for H1, though consolidated beer volume increased by 3.1% for the period. Finally, Novartis (-1.4%) are lower after the Co’s Paragon study just missed the statistical significance levels on its primary endpoints.

FX

DXY - Another day of mild gains for the broad Dollar and index thus far, in a continuation from Friday’s GDP-induced momentum and ahead of an action packed week for the Buck, which will see the currency tackle US-China trade talks in Shanghai, the FOMC’s latest monetary policy decision, US ISM and jobs data. DXY gains more ground above 98.00 having eclipsed last week’s high (98.09) ahead of the YTD high at 98.37, meanwhile today’s docket sees a lack of Tier 1 data and no notable scheduled speakers (with the Fed on blackout until Wednesday evening) 

GBP, EUR, JPY - The Pound has succumbed to further Brexit angst and has given up the psychological 1.2350 mark to the downside, with the move lower coinciding with usual punchy language from UK’s newly appointed Foreign Minister Raab, who reiterated hard lines on Brexit negotiations. As the prospect of a no-deal exit intensified, some desks are observing the declining GBP/USD 3-month risk reversals, which indicate that options skewing leans more towards Sterling weakness in the near-term. Cable has fallen to fresh 2yr lows and currently hovers just under 1.2325 with little by way of immediate tech levels to the downside. Elsewhere, the rising EUR/GBP cross has somewhat cushioned the single currency from Dollar headwinds, with EUR/GBP gaining further tractions above the 0.9000 level. Meanwhile, EUR/USD sees a cluster of options around 1.1100-10 (800mln) and 1.1135-50 (800mln) ahead of today’s NY cut. USD/JPY action is largely dictated by the Dollar ahead of this week’s key risk events and with the BoJ set to publish its latest monetary policy decision overnight. USD/JPY trades closer to the top of a 108.42-70 intraday range with 1bln in options expiring at strikes 108.95-109.05.

AUD, NZD - The antipodeans are somewhat resilient to an extent against the firmer Dollar and remain in tight intraday parameters following last week’s losses. Participants are keeping a close eye on US-Sino trade developments as delegates convene in Shanghai in an attempt to restart talks where it was left off, although officials from US have downplayed expectations of a breakthrough. AUD/USD currently trades a whisker away from 0.6900, with the next support level to the downside highlighted at 0.6890 ahead of the psychological 0.6850 while NZD/USD keeps its head above 0.6600.

TRY - Further gains for the Lira in the aftermath of the CBRT’s deeper-than-forecast rate cut as the prospect of a normalising economy seemingly materialises. Analysts at SocGen also speculate that yield-seekers may be bypassing G10 currencies and instead chasing EM yields. USD/TRY trades around 5.6340 and nearest to the bottom of a 5.6240-6710 parameter

FIXED INCOME

A quiet start to the week for Bonds, as a lack of Tier 1 data points, central bank speakers or supply leaves a stimulus void ahead of a crucial week for central banks with both the Fed and BoE rate decisions occurring. Nonetheless, the Bund is firmer/flat this morning potentially deriving some respite from the quiet start after coming under pressure following Friday’s US GDP beat. Regarding the German 10-year, ING note that the short-term outlook is bullish with resistance levels ahead at 174.80; however, the bank adds that there is strong resistance between 175.20-30. Similarly, Gilts are firmer but generally little changed this morning at 132.30 within a 15-tick range, amidst the lack of catalysts and ahead of Thursday’s BoE rate decision. Finally, and in-line with EU counterparts, UST’s are experiencing a lacklustre start ahead of this week’s FOMC meeting, where expectations are in favour of a 25bps cut though focus will be on policy guidance; prior to Wednesday’s decision we have PCE and ADP data points while the US jobs release ends the week.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are also posting a relatively subdued start to the week, with prices little changed though they have regained the USD 56.00/bbl and USD 63.00/bbl levels to the upside respectively after a brief dip in the complex took them below these levels this morning. Some are attributing this dip to comments from Iran referring to emergency talks on a nuclear agreement as ‘constructive’ which may indicate a easing of tensions in the region which; though the dip was short-lived as there is no sign of respite for UK-Iranian tensions as a second UK warship arrives in the Gulf after Iran seized a UK tanker last week. On the complex, PVM notes that due to the lack of a convincing bullish move on Friday, WTI still has a viable objective to the downside as such a move below near-term support levels in todays session would be sufficient to move the complex lower. In terms of metals, Gold (U/C) is unchanged but towards the bottom of the days range on a lack of catalysts thus far ahead of this weeks aforementioned risk events, similarly copper prices are little changed on the lacklustre risk sentiment.

Bankia (BKIA SM) – Q2 EUR net 195mln vs. Prev. EUR 205mln. Revenue EUR 858mln vs. Prev. EUR 903mln. CET1 ratio 12.9% vs. Prev. 12.6% Q/Q. (Newswires)

Clariant (CLN SW) – SABIC said it has no interest in taking over Clariant but remains keep on a partnership once market conditions improve. (Newswires)

Deutsche Boerse (DB1 GY) – Executive Board said that it does not expected Co.’s discussion with Refinitv on a potential purchase of certain FX business units to be successfully completed. (Newswires)

Eni (ENI IM) – Co. has signed a contract with Kazmuinaigaz for E&P at Abay Block, Kasahgan oil field. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. is said to be looking at reorganising into a holding structure for a more efficient and streamlined operation. (Newswires)

Sports Direct (SPD LD) – FY revenue GBP 3.702bln vs. Prev. GBP 3.36bln, pretax profit GBP 179.2mln. FY net debt GBP 378.5mln vs. Perv. GBP 397.1mln. Co. state that no divided was paid during the year, and the board has decided not to declare a final dividend. Group underlying EBITDA, -6.0%. On House of Fraser Co. states that after years of poor management it will take time to share it into what they want, though they recognise the significant challenges brought. Co. state they are focused on delivering our elevated proposition, and reports of an audit tender being run in 2019 are false; though, Co. has been in contact with audit Co’s in anticipation of a tender process. (Newswires)

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – Co. has sold a 75% stake in Italik Deux as well as a 75% stake in Italik Extension for GBP 423mln, representing an 8.5% discount to the December 2018 value. Deux stage in anticipated to complete in Autumn 2019. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co’s Traton unit (8TRA GY) reported H1 operating profit +25% Y/Y to EUR 1.1bln. Co. affirmed FY guidance. (Newswires)

Zurich Insurance (ZURN SW) – Co. is seeking a buyer for its IFA platform. (Times)

Norsk Hydro (NHY NO) – Co’s CEO states that the US-China trade war is to have a lasting negative impact on demand for aluminium. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week tentative as the upcoming slew of key risk events such as the resumption of US-China trade talks, heavy central bank activity including the FOMC and the latest US NFP jobs data, clouded over last Friday’s record highs on Wall St where tech earnings and better than expected US GDP underpinned stocks. As such, ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed with tech and telecoms front-running the gains in Australia to push the benchmark index to record all-time high, while Tokyo sentiment was subdued by a firmer currency and with earnings in focus. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) weakened amid modest expectations regarding the US-China trade talks in Shanghai this week and following a decline in Chinese Industrial Profits, with underperformance in Hong Kong after violent clashes over the weekend in protests that entered an 8th consecutive week.

FTSE 100

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Q1 net EUR 242.9mln vs. Prev. EUR 309.2mln. Revenue EUR 2.31bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.08bln. Co. has maintained FY guidance due to ancillary revenue. Co. cut FY20 fuel bill to EUR 450mln vs. Prev. EUR 460mln. Co. does not see Boeing 737 Max-related cost savings before 2021. Co. says guidance is heavily dependent on close-in Q2 fares, H2 prices, absence of security events and no negative Brexit developments. (Newswires)

London Stock Exchange (LSE LN) – The USD 27bln merger between LSE and Refinitiv is expected to be finalised within a week, sources say. The merger is expected to go through in-depth antitrust review of up to 18 months in Europe and US. Sources added that the negotiations are at an advanced stage, with Blackstone, LSE and Thomson Reuters in broad agreement on the main aspects of the deal. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Tesco Bank’s GBP 3.7bln loan portfolio has reportedly attracted interest from Santander (SAN SM), RBS (RBS LN) and Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN). Santander is reportedly leading the race and is expected to enter exclusive talks regarding a price for the mortgage portfolio. (Times)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – Co. has confirmed they are in discussions regarding being taken over by Takeaway.com; would result in a combined market value of around GBP 9bln. Additionally, sources indicate that the deal may be announced this week, as both Co’s are scheduled to publish earnings. (BBC/Sky)

Ferguson (FERG LN) – Nelson Peltz, through the Trian investment group, has reportedly told the Co’s board that it wants to explore a sale of the Co’s UK section. For reference, Peltz purchased around a 6% stake in the Co. last month. (Sky)

Associated British Foods (ABF LN) – Primark is reportedly seeking rent cuts of up to 30% in order to bring costs in line with high street competitors. (Sky)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Co. is reportedly preparing for additional job cuts, as the Co. are to reduce their dividend. Additionally, the Co’s CEO Conn is under pressure to convince investors that the poor performance can be turned around. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CENTRICA (CNA LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM REDUCE AT HSBC

JUST EAT (JE/ LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) - T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) have won DoJ approval for their merger, in which USD 5bln in wireless assets will be sold to Dish Networks (DISH). For reference, Deutsche Telekom owns 63% of T-Mobile.

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. has commenced an investigation on whether confidential client data were compromised after a former employee accessed client data via remote access. (FT)

BASF (BAS GY) – Co. plans to invest in a second Tert-Butylamine production plant in China. The plant is planned to be operational in 2020. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Siemens Healthineers (SHL GY) – Q3 revenue EUR 3.57bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.55bln. Adj. profit EUR 543mln vs. Exp. EUR 560.3mln. Co. confirms FY guidance. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) – US President Trump stated that he might apply a tax on French wine in retaliation to France’s new tax affecting US tech firms. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Q2 revenue EUR 8.63bln vs. Exp. EUR 8.4bln. Business EPS EUR 1.31 vs. Exp. EUR 1.25. Co. raised FY business EPS to around 5% vs. Prev. +3-5%. (Newswires)

PSA (UG FP) – Co. is reportedly to move all production from its Ellesmere Port, England and move to a mainland Europe plant if Brexit results in the factory becoming unprofitable. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – Co. is reportedly to approve the purchase of 50-70 Airbus (AIR FP) planes on July 30th., according to Journal du Dimanche. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DANONE (BN FP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT DAVY RESEARCH

KLEPIERRE (LI FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM REDUCE AT ALPHAVALUE

PAN EUROPE

Heineken (HEIA NA) – H1 revenue EUR 11.45bln vs. Exp. EUR 11.50bln. Operating profit EUR 1.78bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.90bln. Net EUR 1.05bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.08bln. H1 consolidated beer volume +3.1% Y/Y. Co. proposes an interim dividend of EUR 0.64/shr vs. Prev. EUR 0.59/shr. (Newswires)

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Co. is reportedly mulling the sale of its South Korean unit. (Newswires)

Air France (AF FP) – Co. is reportedly to approve the purchase of 50-70 Airbus (AIR FP) planes on July 30th., according to Journal du Dimanche. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co’s paragon study has narrowly missed statistical significance on primary endpoint. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week tentative ahead of upcoming slew of key risk events (FOMC, NFP, US-China trade talks) US President Trump said China will probably want to wait on a trade deal and try to delay it until the US election
  • UK Cabinet Minister Gove suggested the government will make intensive efforts to get a better agreement but added that we must operate on assumption of a no-deal Brexit
  • Looking ahead, today’s calendar sees a lack of tier 1 highlights
  • Earnings: Simon Property Group, Baidu, Anadarko Petroleum, Heineken, Sanofi, Ryanair

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week tentative as the upcoming slew of key risk events such as the resumption of US-China trade talks, heavy central bank activity including the FOMC and the latest US NFP jobs data, clouded over last Friday’s record highs on Wall St where tech earnings and better than expected US GDP underpinned stocks. As such, ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed with tech and telecoms front-running the gains in Australia to push the benchmark index to record all-time high, while Tokyo sentiment was subdued by a firmer currency and with earnings in focus. Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) weakened amid modest expectations regarding the US-China trade talks in Shanghai this week and following a decline in Chinese Industrial Profits, with underperformance in Hong Kong after violent clashes over the weekend in protests that entered an 8th consecutive week. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded flat despite the weakness in Tokyo stocks, with demand for bonds subdued as participants were sidelined ahead of tomorrow’s BoJ policy announcement in which it is expected to maintain its policy settings of QQE with YCC control and NIRP at -0.10%.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8821 (Prev. 6.8796)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Jun) Y/Y -3.1% (Prev. 1.1%). (Newswires) Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Jun) Y/Y -2.4% (Prev. -2.3%).

US President Trump said China will probably want to wait on a trade deal and try to delay it until the US election. As a reminder, US and China are to resume face-to-face trade talks in Shanghai this week, although reports noted expectations are modest and that no major breakthrough is anticipated. (Newswires/WSJ)

US is pushing for the WTO for its lenient trade treatment of China and is said to have told USTR Lighthizer to “use all available means” to get the WTO to prevent countries from claiming developing country status if their economic strength means they don’t need beneficial treatment. President Trump also stated that if the WTO does not make "substantial" progress within 90 days, the US will no longer treat certain countries as developing economies. (Associated Press)

Thousands of Hong Kong protesters clashed with police over the weekend in which dozens were arrested as protests regarding the extradition bill continued. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Cabinet Minister Gove stated the government will make intensive efforts to get a better Brexit deal, but added we must operate on assumption we will not and that there will be a no-deal Brexit which we must be ready for. (Sunday Times) Further reports suggest that PM Johnson is to launch the largest advertising campaign since WW2 to get Britain ready for a no-deal Brexit, with an unprecedented marketing blitz on billboards, radio and television. (Telegraph) FT reports that UK chancellor of the exchequer, Sajid Javid, is preparing to announce more than GBP 1bln in increased funding for a no-deal Brexit, according to people familiar with the matter. (FT)

 

Institute for Government (IfG) has warned that there is no such thing as a managed no deal, and that predictions of a clean break from the EU made by hard Brexiteers will not occur. (Guardian)

UK Trade Minister Truss said the main priority is agreeing a FTA with the US and that she will be travelling to the US in the next few weeks for trade discussions, while there separate comments from US President Trump that they are already working on a US-UK free trade deal and that he will spend time with UK PM Johnson. (Newswires/Telegraph)

 

Confederation of British Industry report stated the EU have taken less action and are just as poorly prepared as the UK to cope with a no-deal Brexit, while it added the impact of crashing out will be felt for years. (FT)

 

US President Trump tweeted that France placed a digital tax on technology companies and suggested that if anybody taxes them, it should be the US. President Trump added the US will announce a substantial reciprocal action on Macron’s foolishness shortly and separately commented that he might apply a tax on French wine. In related news, a White House official said the French digital tax shows a lack of commitment to the current OECD negotiations and that the White House is looking at all policy tools in addition to the already launched trade investigation in response to the French tax, while USTR Lighthizer was later said to have prepared a 301 action against France after the announcement of its digital tax. (Newswires)

 

ECB's Nowotny sees rates to be lower in the long-term than they have been historically and states that the ECB should strive for normalization. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Czech Republic at AA-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Finland at AA+; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

DXY slightly pulled back from last Friday’s post-GDP highs to just below the 98.00 level, but with downside limited after reports US President Trump rejected trade adviser Navarro's options for devaluing the USD at a cabinet-level meeting last Friday which ended with the decision not to intervene in the currency. Nonetheless, the greenback’s major counterparts were also lacklustre ahead of this week’s risk events with EUR/USD little changed at the 1.1100 handle and GBP/USD languished at lows last seen in early-2017 amid Brexit fears, with UK Cabinet Minister Gove suggesting the government will make intensive efforts to get a better agreement but added that we must operate on assumption of a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were subdued by the risk averse tone and amid reports Japan’s GPIF began hedging overseas bond investments in a move which sources noted could spur other funds to follow suit and weigh on USD/JPY, while antipodeans were lacklustre due to the tentative risk tone with AUD/USD testing support at the 0.6900 level to the downside.

 

South African President Ramaphosa must place strict limits on a plan to seize land without payment under policies to speed up transfers to the country’s black majority, a panel advising the South African president has said. (FT)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities began the week uneventful with WTI crude futures flat as early mild pressure was nullified by support at the USD 56.00/bbl and amid a lack of bearish catalysts for the energy complex with the latest Baker Hughes rig count showing a drop in oil and gas rigs, while the emergency meeting between Iran and world leaders was said to have been constructive although unresolved issues remain and Iran reiterated it will keep paring back its nuclear commitments. Elsewhere, gold prices were kept rangebound as markets await this week’s FOMC in which the Fed are expected to cut rates for the 1st time in over a decade, and copper prices also languished amid the lack of risk appetite.

 

Baker Hughes (July 26) showed oil rigs -3 at 776, gas rigs -5 at 169, total rigs -8 at 946. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he is not upset at North Korea's recent missile launches and does not blame Turkey for buying the S-400. (Newswires)

Iranian Official Araqchi said emergency meeting with parties related to 2015 nuclear deal was constructive and unresolved issues remain, while he added Iran will continue to reduce its nuclear commitments if the EU cannot save the deal. (Newswires) 

US

The T-plex traded sideways and a little choppy to end the week, seemingly unphased by the GDP data or by Trump dismissing the use of dollar intervention. The US Q2 GDP saw very mild selling 2.1% (exp. 1.8%), but analysts note algos, CTAs, and real money bought the dip. NEC Director Kudlow announcing Trump’s opposition to dollar intervention kept Treasuries supported. At settlement the curve was little changed. US T-note futures (U9) settled 2 ticks lower at 127-07.

US Supreme Court ruled in favour of the Trump administration to permit it to shift military funds to use to construct the border wall. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mostly subdued on cautiousness ahead of this week's heavy slate of key risk events

As such, ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed with tech and telecoms front-running the gains in Australia to push the benchmark index to record all-time high, while Tokyo sentiment was subdued by a firmer currency and with earnings in focus. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) weakened amid modest expectations regarding the US-China trade talks in Shanghai this week and following a decline in Chinese Industrial Profits, with underperformance in Hong Kong after violent clashes over the weekend in protests that entered an 8th consecutive week. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded flat despite the weakness in Tokyo stocks, with demand for bonds subdued as participants were sidelined ahead of tomorrow’s BoJ policy announcement in which it is expected to maintain its policy settings of QQE with YCC control and NIRP at -0.10%.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly subdued on cautiousness ahead of this week's heavy slate of key risk events
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week tentative as the upcoming slew of key risk events such as the resumption of US-China trade talks, heavy central bank activity including the FOMC and the latest US NFP jobs data, clouds over last Friday’s record highs on Wall St where stocks were underpinned by tech earnings and better than expected US GDP data. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) are mixed with tech and telecoms front-running the gains in Australia following similar outperformance in their counterparts stateside, while Tokyo sentiment is dampened by a firmer currency and with earnings in focus. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. are (-0.3%) subdued amid modest expectations regarding the US-China trade talks in Shanghai this week and following a decline in Chinese Industrial Profits, with underperformance in Hong Kong after violent clashes over the weekend as protests entered an 8th consecutive week.

In FX markets, the DXY slightly pulled back from last Friday’s post-GDP highs to just below the 98.00 level, but with downside also limited after reports US President Trump rejected trade adviser Navarro's options for devaluing the USD at a cabinet-level meeting on Friday which ended with the decision not to intervene in the currency. The greenback’s major counterparts are also lacklustre ahead of this week’s risk events with EUR/USD little changed at the 1.1100 handle and GBP/USD languishes at lows last seen in early-2017 amid Brexit fears, with UK Cabinet Minister Gove suggesting the government will make intensive efforts to get a better agreement but added that we must operate on assumption of a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are subdued by the risk averse tone and amid reports Japan’s GPIF began hedging overseas bond investments in a move which sources noted could spur other funds to follow suit and weigh on USD/JPY, while antipodeans are lacklustre due to the tentative risk tone with AUD/USD testing support at the 0.6900 level to the downside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat despite the weakness in Tokyo stocks, with demand for bonds subdued as participants are sidelined ahead of tomorrow’s BoJ policy announcement in which it is expected to maintain it policy settings of QQE with YCC control and NIRP at -0.10%.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US-China trade talks resume, Bank of Jinzhou gets a bailout, Industrial Profits decline 3.1%Y/Y
content:
Bank of Jinzhou (416 HK) - Co. gets a bailout with ICBC (1398 HK) to acquire an 11% stake for CNY 3.0bln, while China Cinda and China Great Wall will also acquire stakes in the bank. (Newswires)

Citic Resources (1205 HK) - Co. H1 net HKD 362.1mln vs. Prev. HKD 529.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Gemdale Properties and Investment (535 HK) - Co. issues a positive profit alert in which it guides H1 net to increase at least 70% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Huatai Securities (601688 CH) - Lock up period for 1.09bln of Co. A-Shrs will end and Co. will start trading at August 2nd. (Newswires)

Lianhua Supermarket Holdings (980 HK) - Co. guides H1 net to decline significantly. (Newswires)

Jutal Offshore Oil Services (3303 HK) - Co. awarded CNY 3.0bln contract. (Newswires)

Tech - China is said to have completed 2nd investment round regarding USD 29bln fund which is targeted at the domestic chip industry. (Newswires)

Protests - Thousands of Hong Kong protesters clashed with police over the weekend in which dozens were arrested as protests regarding the extradition bill continued. (Newswires)

Trade

US and China are to resume face-to-face trade talks in Shanghai this week, although reports notes expectations are modest and no major breakthrough is anticipated. (WSJ)

US President Trump said China will probably want to wait on a trade deal and try to delay it until the US election. In related news, NEC Director Kudlow said if talks with China go well next week, then US would not expect new tariffs, while President Trump may use tariffs as a tool if talks do not go well. (Newswires)

US is pressing the WTO regarding its lenient trade treatment of China and is said to have told USTR Lighthizer to “use all available means” to get the WTO to prevent countries from claiming developing country status if their economic strength means they don’t need beneficial treatment. President Trump also stated that if the WTO does not make "substantial" progress within 90 days, the US will no longer treat certain countries as developing economies. (Associated Press)

Data Recap 

  • Chinese Industrial Profits (Jun) Y/Y -3.1% (Prev. 1.1%). (Newswires)
  • Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Jun) Y/Y -2.4% (Prev. -2.3%)
